captions.text:
Way back in the good old days when a &quot;loot
box&quot; was just where renaissance faire performers

stored their musical instruments, we used
to debate over whether video games are an

art form. These days it&#39;s generally agreed
that they are, albeit in the sense that architecture

is an art form, y&#39;know. Your average triple-A
game is like a newly constructed skyscraper

- imposing, functional, and full of people
I need to murder. But there aren&#39;t many games

that are akin to the experience of, say, walking
around an art museum. Of slowly gliding through

silent, mostly empty rooms, standing in front
of an installation and inspecting it with

a finger to your chin as you think to yourself,
&quot;Hm. I am bored out of my fucking skull. I

hope that attractive cloakroom attendant is
watching and thinking what a cool and sexy

intellectual I must be because I would desperately
rather be playing Crash Bandicoot.&quot; But now

that experience has been faithfully recreated
by Kentucky Route Zero. An episodic game that

recently concluded with its fifth chapter.
Surprised to see someone still doing the episodic

game thing since Telltale Games choked to
death on its own officially licensed farts,

but this one started in 2013, so I guess that
lines up. This also means that the game took

longer to finish than the second World War,
and had it been any more boring might&#39;ve had
a similar body count.

Kentucky Route Zero might be best classified
as a point and click adventure, although &quot;adventure&quot;

implies things like puzzles and challenge
and adversity so we might more accurately

use the phrase &quot;point and click sequence.&quot;
Your interactivity is limited to dialog choices

that ultimately don&#39;t change much and moving
around to get to the next one. So not a lot

of gameplay to work with, but I have a job
to do so by Jacob&#39;s cream crackers I&#39;m going

to damn well try to whine about it. I wouldn&#39;t
recommend using a controller, like I did,

because the arty cameras and clashing of gears
between 2D and 3D movement mean that the direction

you move in when you press the analog stick
is a matter left to the whims of fate. Oh

come on, Yahtzee, clearly this game is a project
created by artists with a specific vision

rather than one of you video game insider
types who want to put everything in classifiable

boxes. You stomping in here demanding intuitive
movement and boss fights is like marching

into a high class restaurant and loudly demanding
to know where the children&#39;s ball pit is. Fine.

In Kentucky Route Zero you play Conway, an
ageing truck driver in an ageing truck on

a job to deliver antiques from a shop that&#39;s
about to close down. Is that enough elements

estabishing the theme of &quot;entropy&quot; yet, viewers?
What if we also give the truck driver a bad

leg? And a T-shirt with &quot;everything fucking
dies&quot; on the front in big letters? Struggling

to find an address that doesn&#39;t seem to exist,
Conway is directed by various mysterious figures

to the Route Zero, a mysterious world of underground
tunnels and secret backroads where dwelleth

a forgotten vein of middle America. What follows
is a melancholy odyssey reminiscent of Alice

in Wonderland if it were directed by David
Lynch and if all the talking doorknobs and

shit were replaced with struggling small business
owners, passively trying to muddle along in

a world that is leaving them behind as an
insidious all-pervading company slowly eats

their support out from under them. A company
that I suspect might be a metaphor for death.

That&#39;s going off the fact that it appears
to be entirely staffed with skeletons, but

I&#39;m no literary analyst. Maybe it&#39;s a metaphor
for how difficult it is to find a good osteopath

these days. Conway himself takes a back seat
as the game becomes a sequence of introductions

to new characters, and the little islands
in the darkness that are the glimpses into
their lives.

Considering how long it&#39;s taken for all the
episodes to come out, one might reasonably

wonder what was taking so long, &#39;cos I can
list a few things they certainly didn&#39;t need

much time for - gameplay design, voice acting,
and probably not graphics, either, considering

that a lot of it consists of stark gradients
against blackness and the characters are simple

faceless figures that look like they could
be recreated by a bored schoolboy artfully

folding his sandwich wrappers. No, I think
the writing is where the time went, and in

fairness, there&#39;s a hell of a lot of it. Conway&#39;s
party gradually fills up with quirky characters

- a TV repairwoman, an android synth-pop duo,
a little boy who&#39;s best friends with a giant

eagle and constantly wears a suit for no established
reason, possibly to avoid being mistaken for

a tasty worm - and they all have unique personalities,
viewpoints and interactions with the many

unique individuals they meet on their journey
- although some of those blur together a bit.

In the fourth chapter you&#39;re all on a boat
and suddenly there&#39;s this theremin player

on the squad and I honestly couldn&#39;t remember
if she&#39;d been properly introduced or just

turned up in the background like mildew in
the shower.

And then chapter five introduces a whole townful
of new characters and the already faint sliver

of shit that I currently give for these people&#39;s
lives has to be divided even further and nobody

is getting a full dingleberry. I admire Kentucky
Route Zero more than I like it. I admire the

thoughtful writing and the creativity behind
its ideas. I also admire people who know how

to survive in the wild by chewing tree bark
for nutrients but I wouldn&#39;t consider it a

recommendation of the lifestyle, and I have
trouble recommending any game that puts me

to fucking sleep. I suppose there&#39;s no hope
of getting out of this without sounding like

a jaded video game insider with an attention
span so worn down to the nub I can barely

focus long enough to navigate the straw on
my Capri-Sun into my drooling mouth, but Kentucky

Route Zero wouldn&#39;t even let me into the third
chapter until I watched an entire three act

play. Not a fun play, like that one with the
horse where Harry Potter gets his knob out

- a pretentious student play where three characters
sit unmoving in a diner verbally skating around

the fucking point for twenty minutes. It would
even fucking pause if I wasn&#39;t directing the
camera at whoever&#39;s turn it was to speak,

ensuring there was no escape, and forcing
me to become an instrument of my own torment,

the way my mum used to glue thumbtacks to
the palms of my hands before I went to bed.

Didn&#39;t fucking stop me, mum! Just means I
get awkward stiffies when I go to OfficeMax.

I can&#39;t help comparing Kentucky Route Zero
to another game I tried this week, a free

demo called Star Fetchers Pilot. A very amateurish-looking
side-on hack and slash with art that looks

like MS Paint stepped on a turd and skidded
through a French window, but with a deliberate

punk sensibility and humour that brought to
mind Suda51&#39;s best works, and a unique core

mechanic based around clicking and dragging
the end of your sword with the mouse that&#39;s

more like colouring in than combat but has
the interesting raw experimental feel of,

say, Sexy Hiking. All in all it was a million
times less polished and a million times more

interesting, and you know what, if Star Fetchers
tried to make a point about the disenfranchisement

of America&#39;s forgotten underclass - which
it arguably does - I&#39;d be a lot more likely

to listen. Call me a philistine, but gameplay
and challenge can actually be a useful tool

for pacing a story, and going without is like
a film going without proper editing, or getting

thrown out of OfficeMax before you can climax
over the Tipp-Ex.
